thread.section_title: Financial Review - Business, Finance and Investment News | afr.com
thread.title: ACCC knocks back taxi operator's anti-Uber app
thread.title_full: ACCC knocks back taxi operator's anti-Uber app | afr.com

author: Shaun Drummond
title: ACCC knocks back taxi operator's anti-Uber app
text:
The ACCC says a new global taxi app would have lessened competition in taxi bookings Paul Jones by Shaun Drummond Competition watchdog chief Rod Simms says that if it approves new international taxi booking app ihail it could allow separate taxi networks that control 80 per cent of cab bookings and payments to join forces.
In a draft determination released on Monday, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission chairman said ihail's shareholders control half of all taxis in Australia and allowing them to offer one booking app could have a "significant impact on competition".
"In each city there is just two main taxi networks," Mr Simms told The Australian Financial Review . "Here what they are asking us to do is allow the two networks that have in excess of 40 per cent of taxi fleets in each city combine their apps into a single app and that could well mean that they are in a dominant position."
In October 2014, iHail Pty Ltd was registered with the Australian Securities and Investments Commission and iHail Holdings was registered in Britain on July 6.
ACCC chairman Rod Simms said if it approves the ihail app, it could entrench the dominance of Cabcharge, Silver Top Taxis and Yellow Cabs. Josh Robenstone It is backed by taxi networks in Australia – including Yellow Cabs, Silver Top Taxi Service, Black and White Cabs, Suburban Taxis – and listed group Cabcharge, which owns competing taxi networks. Together they own most of the taxi networks in Australia.
Other shareholders include US-based Taxi Services Inc. and Minneapolis and Mobile Tracking and Data, which provides the taxi dispatch booking system for the Cabcharge networks.
On May 26, the networks asked the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to grant an interim authorisation to the app, which will allow people to book a taxi from any of the affiliated networks. The joint venture also plans to add more networks.
Mr Simms said if it did it would "guarantee that from its launch, the ihail app would have a larger fleet of taxis, in a broader range of locations, than any existing taxi booking apps. Depending on the rate of take up of the ihail app amongst other taxi networks, it could potentially grow to include all taxi networks in any area".
 He told the Financial Review the ACCC understands the inroads Uber, goCatch and Ingogo, among others, are making into Cabcharge and the network's market share. But he said combined this still only amounts to 10 to 15 per cent.
"Do we want the two main taxi networks to combine? As apps become more important [in taxi bookings], it could be that we have blessed the two main operators getting together," he said.
"The growth in [new] apps is being driven by competition to attract drivers and customers. ihail will achieve a potentially dominant position from launch – not through competition, but because of the larger fleet of taxis its ownership structure delivers."
He said ihail would also only use the Cabcharge payment system, which effectively reversed a recent agreement the ACCC approved to allow competitors to process Cabcharge cards .
"Here we have a system where what we have achieved in a taxi cab gets locked out of this arrangement with ihail," he said.
"Cabcharge have had an entrenched position for a long time. We took them to court five years ago, and we were just about to take them to court again. Now we find this comes along."
The draft decision is open to consultation now, with a final decision likely at the end of November. It would be a major a blow to Cabcharge in its fight against Uber and other new rivals if approved. But Cabcharge has said ihail is separate to the new national booking app it is developing that will be offered alongside its network owners' state based apps.
Like existing new apps, including Uber, goCatch and Ingogo, passengers would pay for the fare via the app on Cabcharge's payment network, with no money exchanged with the taxi driver.
ihail would also allow passengers to pay an extra amount to encourage taxi drivers to pick up their fare first. But the ACCC said this could disadvantage poorer people
goCatch co-cheif Ned Moorfield said the ACCC had made the right decision. "The difference between them and us is that ihail is grouping networks together and they can have quite a bit of influence over their taxi operators," he said.
"They could say to the operators that your drivers can't use any other apps."
